response.answer_text: You mean the one-who-must-not-be-named? I thought that was known as Voldemort? Or is it “The Name” or “HaShem” (השם) as G-D is referred to in Hebrew? On second thoughts, no… umm - that means “The Name”. Not “No Name”.  I found it in the labyrinths of my cognition. There’s no whataboutery involved, I promise.  Allow me to introduce you to “No Name”. Say Hello to “No Name”.  Image Source This is an actual brand in Canada, the products of which are commonly found in “The Real Canadian Superstore” chains, as well as in the “No Frills” chain (at least that’s what it was several years back when I used to live in Canada). For more information, visit: No Name (brand) - Wikipedia Poor people, graduate students, people of colour, immigrants or hapless people (like me) who’d check more than one of the above-mentioned categories belonged to the target customer groups of the “no name” products. We were the ones who wouldn’t care about whether their chicken or vegetable broth has less or more sodium than Campbell’s as long as it’s broth, and as long as it’s cheapest, even while coming in a carton. Names not only carry meaning, but also a lot of values and the relationship between these two variables are often circular. Having “no name” entailed having a cheap and affordable product. Even though no deliberate branding was intended, to keep away from cost-cutting in establishing a name, “no name” became quite famous based on its “strange” criterion, to catch the attention of Buzzfeed: 21 Of The Most Hilariously Honest "No Name" Products  How one of the “no name” products would look. Image Source  An even bigger question is: Can a “no name” mean a no-name? What if the meaningless of a “no name” is not apparent to all? That’s possible too. For example, while living in Taiwan and Singapore, I’d love shopping for specific kinds of household goods from a particular chain, called “Muji”. They had nice, reasonably durable products, and were quite affordably priced too.  A Muji store, in Singapore; Image Source Now, when I hear “muji”, it doesn’t mean anything; but I tend to associate the word with “moja” (not “mawja”) in my native language (Bengali), which means: socks. Not a big deal...just one of those things of how you figure out living in foreign lands —by associating them with their apparent similarity in something. But then, the originally intended muji is not remotely related to ‘moja’ (i.e. socks). The name Muji is derived from the first part of Mujirushi Ryōhin, translated as No Brand Quality Goods: Muji - Wikipedia Muji means “no brand”, just very similar to the “No Name” of Canada. Same thing, but different names. No names want to signify no meanings. But that doesn’t become very apparent, unless you know the language in which the words hold some meaning and value to you, the languages in this context being Japanese and English. In India, the name “Anamika” literally means “the one with no name”. It also means the ring finger, because apparently we couldn’t name the “ring finger” as ring finger, so we gave it the name of ‘no name’. But it’s still a name. There are thousands of Indian girls with the name “Anamika” (and a famous Indian designer). There are thousands of “No Name” products in Canada. There are hundreds of “Muji” stores. Some names could mean “no name”, but you can’t say the same about “no name”-s. They do mean something. Otherwise, they wouldn’t be there to begin with.

I read through the answers you’ve received so far and noticed that nobody had mentioned this name yet: Nergüi (Нэргуй) Nergüi is a unisex name of Mongolian origin which literally means “no-name.” According to its page on the website Behind the Name, Nergüi was traditonally given to trick malicious spirits, although I haven’t located another source to confirm that— it may simply be best to ask a Mongolian for history and context. In any case, Nergüi is indeed a name that means “no name.” Cheers
